comments.body: https://github.com/pulibrary/figgy/commit/c91c77e9c4efef166ba51a0ba00fe44e1fd403f2 was needed in order to prevent certain errors from being raised within the Bootstrap Modal component (this was somehow related to a conflict in event handling within Material UI components).

https://github.com/samvera/browse-everything/pull/331 and https://github.com/samvera-labs/browse-everything-redux-react/pull/45 need to be merged upstream, and then https://github.com/pulibrary/figgy/compare/issues-3724-jrgriffiniii-browse-everything-2.0.0alpha1 can be updated for a pull request.

https://github.com/samvera-labs/browse-everything-redux-react/pull/45 required an update to the `yarn.lock` which seems to break without deleting and replacing this file outright. I am working to test this once again with a fresh `git clone`.
I'm finding some possible race conditions during the Google authorization process within Figgy, but these are also breaking my browser debugger, so perhaps these are local environment problems.
This was not a race condition, but instead seems to be an issue with the Google API: https://github.com/samvera-labs/browse-everything-redux-react/pull/45#issuecomment-592645807

I think in the database the BCE dates are saved with a minus (-). so a math validation will still be valid. 
BCE latest_date : -100     
BCE earliest_date: -300 
`latest_date > earliest_date => true`

comments.body:
[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/29040305/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/29040305)

Coverage remained the same at 79.51% when pulling **aacbd8f7de948504bb9f19aa7ae3fbe2f744bbbd on dependabot/bundler/rake-13.0.1** into **205a8c6b3ea45f7b1229048b440fe4046b57a86f on master**.

There were roughly 3400 `Spotlight::CustomFields` attached to that exhibit for the `type` field from the JSON-LD, all with the same field but with different slugs. For some reason on import it's not recognizing that those fields already exist, apparently.

For now I just deleted all the dups and it's much faster.
Selections from Near East Collections has about 6k dups, I'm gonna kill those too.

I'm going to go to sleep. I tracked this down to this:

When an item imports it checks to make sure that a given key doesn't already exist as a label for all the fields that exist. The problem is to do that it uses `Spotlight::CustomField#label`, which first checks the blacklight config to see if the user has overridden that label.

The labels are mapped here: https://github.com/projectblacklight/spotlight/blob/master/app/models/spotlight/resources/iiif_manifest.rb#L114

The comparison happens here:
https://github.com/projectblacklight/spotlight/blob/master/app/models/spotlight/resources/iiif_manifest.rb#L109

The problem is on import the key is `@type`, but a user has changed it to `Type` for an existing field. This check should really be making sure the field name doesn't already exist. We should patch that.

IN the meantime, I'm changing those fields for Slavic and Near East Collections back to `@type` as a label to stop proliferation and hiding them from display.

As a final note, you can check for the proliferating things like this:
```
Spotlight::CustomField.all.select{|v| v.slug.length > 30}.size
```
The slugs get a UUID, so they're real long.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/29021302/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/29021302)

Coverage remained the same at 100.0% when pulling **746b1c6fc6b0508a6f9710212da03d9e9073863d on duplicate_fields** into **1cc466ac4769b581851e7804d9c7e90489ed79dd on master**.

Provision solr 8 boxes for use by catalog-staging

comments.body:
Migrating solr data to a new znode.

1. On each solr box, create a copy of /etc/defaults/solr.in.sh to /etc/defaults/_new_solr.in.sh. Update the `ZK_HOST` param to append the new znode. When it's time to edit this config file, you can just swap in the copy.
1. Stop solr on all boxes.
1. On one box only:
   1. Start a tmux session.
   1. `cd /opt/solr`
   1. `bin/solr zk mkroot /solr7 -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk cp -r zk:/clusterstate.json zk:/solr7/clusterstate.json -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk cp -r zk:/aliases.json zk:/solr7/aliases.json -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk cp -r zk:/live_nodes zk:/solr7/live_nodes -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk cp -r zk:/overseer zk:/solr7/overseer -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk cp -r zk:/overseer_elect zk:/solr7/overseer_elect -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk cp -r zk:/collections zk:/solr7/collections -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk cp -r zk:/configs zk:/solr7/configs -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. There are a couple others. Move everything except `/solr8` (there is also a `/zookeeper` but it's only visible form the zookeeper cli).
   1. Check the new znode contents: `bin/solr zk ls /solr7 -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. Delete those data from their old locations.
   1. `bin/solr zk rm -r /clusterstate.json -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk rm -r /aliases.json -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk rm -r /live_nodes -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk rm -r /overseer -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk rm -r /overseer_elect -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk rm -r /collections -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk rm -r /configs -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. Check the root node contents: `bin/solr zk ls / -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
      1. The only contents should be `/solr7`, and `/solr8`.
1. On each solr server, modify the solr.in.sh configs by swapping in the files you created in step 1. Ensure the owner remains `root:deploy`.
1. Start solr again.

Migrating solr data to a new znode. With production values.

1. On each solr box, create a copy of /etc/defaults/solr.in.sh to /etc/defaults/_new_solr.in.sh. Update the `ZK_HOST` param to append the new znode. When it's time to edit this config file, you can just swap in the copy.
1. Stop solr on all boxes.
1. On one box only:
   1. Start a tmux session.
   1. `cd /opt/solr`
   1. `bin/solr zk mkroot /solr7 -z lib-zk1:2181,lib-zk2:2181,lib-zk3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk cp -r zk:/clusterstate.json zk:/solr7/clusterstate.json -z lib-zk1:2181,lib-zk2:2181,lib-zk3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk cp -r zk:/aliases.json zk:/solr7/aliases.json -z lib-zk1:2181,lib-zk2:2181,lib-zk3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk cp -r zk:/live_nodes zk:/solr7/live_nodes -z lib-zk1:2181,lib-zk2:2181,lib-zk3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk cp -r zk:/overseer zk:/solr7/overseer -z lib-zk1:2181,lib-zk2:2181,lib-zk3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk cp -r zk:/overseer_elect zk:/solr7/overseer_elect -z lib-zk1:2181,lib-zk2:2181,lib-zk3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk cp -r zk:/collections zk:/solr7/collections -z lib-zk1:2181,lib-zk2:2181,lib-zk3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk cp -r zk:/configs zk:/solr7/configs -z lib-zk1:2181,lib-zk2:2181,lib-zk3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk cp -r zk:/configs zk:/solr7/autoscaling -z lib-zk1:2181,lib-zk2:2181,lib-zk3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk cp -r zk:/configs zk:/solr7/autoscaling.json -z lib-zk1:2181,lib-zk2:2181,lib-zk3:2181`
   1. Check the new znode contents: `bin/solr zk ls /solr7 -z lib-zk1:2181,lib-zk2:2181,lib-zk3:2181`
   1. Delete those data from their old locations.
   1. `bin/solr zk rm -r /clusterstate.json -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk rm -r /aliases.json -z lib-zk1:2181,lib-zk2:2181,lib-zk3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk rm -r /live_nodes -z lib-zk1:2181,lib-zk2:2181,lib-zk3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk rm -r /overseer -z lib-zk1:2181,lib-zk2:2181,lib-zk3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk rm -r /overseer_elect -z lib-zk1:2181,lib-zk2:2181,lib-zk3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk rm -r /collections -z lib-zk1:2181,lib-zk2:2181,lib-zk3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk rm -r /configs -z lib-zk1:2181,lib-zk2:2181,lib-zk3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk rm -r /autoscaling -z lib-zk1:2181,lib-zk2:2181,lib-zk3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk rm -r /autoscaling.json -z lib-zk1:2181,lib-zk2:2181,lib-zk3:2181`
   1. Check the root node contents: `bin/solr zk ls / -z lib-zk1:2181,lib-zk2:2181,lib-zk3:2181`
      1. The only contents should be `/solr7` and `/solr8` (`/zookeeper` is also at the root level but is only visible from the zookeeper cli).
1. On each solr server, modify the solr.in.sh configs by swapping in the files you created in step 1. Ensure the owner remains `root:deploy`.
1. Start solr again.
